content: Hello! Thanks for reaching out to XYZ Home Services. How can I help you with your heating, cooling, or air quality needs today? To get started, can I have your name please?
Yeah, I need someone to look at my AC. It’s blowing warm air. Before we waste time, what are you going to charge me for this?

Thank you for letting me know about your AC issue. Pricing can vary depending on the exact problem, but I can provide a general estimate. May I please have your name and address so I can give you the most accurate information?
Why do you need my name just to tell me a price? This is why I hate dealing with companies like this.

I understand your frustration. We ask for your address to ensure you’re in our service area, and your name helps us keep track of requests. If you prefer, I can give you a basic estimate range for AC service. Typical diagnosis fees start at $89, but the final cost will depend on what's wrong. Would you like to continue?
So it starts at $89 just to show up? What a scam. And then you’ll tack on fees for whatever you find, right?

The $89 covers the professional diagnosis of the problem. Any repairs needed would be quoted before work begins, so there would be no surprises. There are no hidden fees – we always provide up-front pricing. If you’d like, I can schedule a time for a technician to take a look, or answer any other questions you may have.
No, I don’t want to give out any information before I know who’s coming. Can I talk to the actual technician? I don’t need all this back-and-forth.

I understand wanting direct answers. I can only connect you with a technician after scheduling an appointment. If you’d like more information about who will be coming, I can share details once your booking is set. Would you like to schedule, or is there something else I can help with?
No, you’re not hearing me. I want to talk to a real person before I give out ANY info or agree to anything. Forget it, this is too much trouble.
reason: Customer refused to provide required info, declined further contact.
